Category.desc: MISRA C++ 2023
Category.name: MISRACPP2023

Category.desc: Rule 4.1.3 (Required) There shall be no occurrence of undefined or critical unspecified behaviour
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-4_1_3

Category.desc: Rule 4.1.2 (Advisory) Deprecated features should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-4_1_2

Category.desc: Rule 9.6.1 (Advisory) The goto statement should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_6_1

Category.desc: Rule 9.6.3 (Required) The goto statement shall jump to a label declared later in the function body
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_6_3

Category.desc: Rule 28.3.1 (Required) Predicates shall not have persistent side effects
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-28_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 9.6.2 (Required) A goto statement shall reference a label in a surrounding block
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_6_2

Category.desc: Rule 9.6.5 (Required) A function with non-void return type shall return a value on all paths
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_6_5

Category.desc: Rule 5.10.1 (Required) User-defined identifiers shall have an appropriate form
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_10_1

Category.desc: Rule 9.6.4 (Required) A function declared with the [[noreturn]] attribute shall not return
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_6_4

Category.desc: Rule 0.2.3 (Advisory) Types with limited visibility should be used at least once
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_2_3

Category.desc: Rule 0.2.4 (Advisory) Functions with limited visibility should be used at least once
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_2_4

Category.desc: Rule 22.4.1 (Required) The literal value zero shall be the only value assigned to errno
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-22_4_1

Category.desc: Rule 9.2.1 (Required) An explicit type conversion shall not be an expression statement
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_2_1

Category.desc: Rule 11.3.2 (Advisory) The declaration of an object should contain no more than two levels of pointer indirection
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-11_3_2

Category.desc: Rule 11.3.1 (Advisory) Variables of array type should not be declared
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-11_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 0.2.1 (Advisory) Variables with limited visibility should be used at least once
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_2_1

Category.desc: Rule 18.3.2 (Required) An exception of class type shall be caught by const reference or reference
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-18_3_2

Category.desc: Rule 0.2.2 (Required) A named function parameter shall be used at least once
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_2_2

Category.desc: Rule 18.3.1 (Advisory) There should be at least one exception handler to catch all otherwise unhandled exceptions
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-18_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 18.3.3 (Required) Handlers for a function-try-block of a constructor or destructor shall not refer to non-static members from their class or its bases
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-18_3_3

Category.desc: Rule 10.1.2 (Required) The volatile qualifier shall be used appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-10_1_2

Category.desc: Rule 19.1.3 (Required) All identifiers used in the controlling expression of #if or #elif preprocessing directives shall be defined prior to evaluation
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_1_3

Category.desc: Rule 8.20.1 (Advisory) An unsigned arithmetic operation with constant operands should not wrap
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_20_1

Category.desc: Rule 10.1.1 (Advisory) The target type of a pointer or lvalue reference parameter should be const-qualified appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-10_1_1

Category.desc: Rule 19.1.2 (Required) All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_1_2

Category.desc: Rule 19.1.1 (Required) The defined preprocessor operator shall be used appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_1_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.0.1 (Advisory) Parentheses should be used to make the meaning of an expression appropriately explicit
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 30.0.2 (Required) Reads and writes on the same file stream shall be separated by a positioning operation
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-30_0_2

Category.desc: Rule 6.9.2 (Advisory) The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_9_2

Category.desc: Rule 6.9.1 (Required) The same type aliases shall be used in all declarations of the same entity
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_9_1

Category.desc: Rule 6.5.2 (Advisory) Internal linkage should be specified appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_5_2

Category.desc: Dir 5.7.2 (Advisory) Sections of code should not be "commented out"
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_7_2

Category.desc: Rule 6.5.1 (Advisory) A function or object with external linkage should be introduced in a header file
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_5_1

Category.desc: Rule 5.7.1 (Required) The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C-style comment
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_7_1

Category.desc: Rule 5.7.3 (Required) Line-splicing shall not be used in // comments
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_7_3

Category.desc: Rule 30.0.1 (Required) The C Library input/output functions shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-30_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.11 (Required) An argument passed via ellipsis shall have an appropriate type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_11

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.10 (Required) Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_10

Category.desc: Rule 21.10.1 (Required) The features of <cstdarg> shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_10_1

Category.desc: Rule 28.6.1 (Required) The argument to std::move shall be a non-const lvalue
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-28_6_1

Category.desc: Rule 21.10.2 (Required) The standard header file <csetjmp> shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_10_2

Category.desc: Rule 28.6.2 (Required) Forwarding references and std::forward shall be used together
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-28_6_2

Category.desc: Rule 9.5.2 (Required) A for-range-initializer shall contain at most one function call
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_5_2

Category.desc: Rule 8.18.1 (Mandatory) An object or subobject must not be copied to an overlapping object
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_18_1

Category.desc: Rule 9.5.1 (Advisory) Legacy for statements should be simple
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_5_1

Category.desc: Rule 15.1.5 (Required) A class shall only define an initializer-list constructor when it is the only constructor
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-15_1_5

Category.desc: Rule 15.1.4 (Advisory) All direct, non-static data members of a class should be initialized before the class object is accessible
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-15_1_4

Category.desc: Rule 4.6.1 (Required) Operations on a memory location shall be sequenced appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-4_6_1

Category.desc: Rule 15.1.3 (Required) Conversion operators and constructors that are callable with a single argument shall be explicit
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-15_1_3

Category.desc: Rule 21.10.3 (Required) The facilities provided by the standard header file <csignal> shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_10_3

Category.desc: Rule 15.1.2 (Advisory) All constructors of a class should explicitly initialize all of its virtual base classes and immediate base classes
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-15_1_2

Category.desc: Rule 8.14.1 (Advisory) The right-hand operand of a logical && or || operator should not contain persistent side effects
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_14_1

Category.desc: Rule 24.5.2 (Required) The C++ Standard Library functions memcpy, memmove and memcmp from <cstring> shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-24_5_2

Category.desc: Rule 8.18.2 (Advisory) The result of an assignment operator should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_18_2

Category.desc: Rule 28.6.3 (Required) An object shall not be used while in a potentially moved-from state
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-28_6_3

Category.desc: Rule 24.5.1 (Required) The character handling functions from <cctype> and <cwctype> shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-24_5_1

Category.desc: Rule 28.6.4 (Required) The result of std::remove, std::remove_if, std::unique and empty shall be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-28_6_4

Category.desc: Rule 8.7.1 (Required) Pointer arithmetic shall not form an invalid pointer
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_7_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.3.2 (Advisory) The built-in unary + operator should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_3_2

Category.desc: Rule 0.1.2 (Required) The value returned by a function shall be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_1_2

Category.desc: Rule 18.4.1 (Required) Exception-unfriendly functions shall be noexcept
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-18_4_1

Category.desc: Rule 0.1.1 (Advisory) A value should not be unnecessarily written to a local object
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_1_1

Category.desc: Rule 19.6.1 (Advisory) The #pragma directive and the _Pragma operator should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_6_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.7.2 (Required) Subtraction between pointers shall only be applied to pointers that address elements of the same array
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_7_2

Category.desc: Rule 15.1.1 (Required) An object's dynamic type shall not be used from within its constructor or destructor
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-15_1_1

Category.desc: Rule 19.2.3 (Required) The ' or " or \ characters and the /* or // character sequences shall not occur in a header file name
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_2_3

Category.desc: Rule 10.2.1 (Required) An enumeration shall be defined with an explicit underlying type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-10_2_1

Category.desc: Rule 19.2.2 (Required) The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_2_2

Category.desc: Rule 19.2.1 (Required) Precautions shall be taken in order to prevent the contents of a header file being included more than once
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_2_1

Category.desc: Rule 10.2.3 (Required) The numeric value of an unscoped enumeration with no fixed underlying type shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-10_2_3

Category.desc: Rule 8.3.1 (Advisory) The built-in unary - operator should not be applied to an expression of unsigned type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 10.2.2 (Advisory) Unscoped enumerations should not be declared
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-10_2_2

Category.desc: Rule 12.3.1 (Required) The union keyword shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-12_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 21.6.2 (Required) Dynamic memory shall be managed automatically
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_6_2

Category.desc: Rule 21.6.3 (Required) Advanced memory management shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_6_3

Category.desc: Rule 7.0.6 (Required) Assignment between numeric types shall be appropriate
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_0_6

Category.desc: Rule 21.6.4 (Required) If a project defines either a sized or unsized version of a global operator delete, then both shall be defined
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_6_4

Category.desc: Rule 21.6.5 (Required) A pointer to an incomplete class type shall not be deleted
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_6_5

Category.desc: Rule 7.0.3 (Required) The numerical value of a character shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_0_3

Category.desc: Rule 7.0.2 (Required) There shall be no conversion to type bool
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_0_2

Category.desc: Rule 7.0.5 (Required) Integral promotion and the usual arithmetic conversions shall not change the signedness or the type category of an operand
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_0_5

Category.desc: Rule 7.0.4 (Required) The operands of bitwise operators and shift operators shall be appropriate
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_0_4

Category.desc: Rule 7.0.1 (Required) There shall be no conversion from type bool
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 5.0.1 (Advisory) Trigraph-like sequences should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 13.1.2 (Required) An accessible base class shall not be both virtual and non-virtual in the same hierarchy
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-13_1_2

Category.desc: Rule 13.1.1 (Advisory) Classes should not be inherited virtually
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-13_1_1

Category.desc: Rule 21.2.1 (Required) The library functions atof, atoi, atol and atoll from <cstdlib> shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_2_1

Category.desc: Rule 6.2.4 (Required) A header file shall not contain definitions of functions or objects that are non-inline and have external linkage
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_2_4

Category.desc: Rule 6.2.3 (Required) The source code used to implement an entity shall appear only once
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_2_3

Category.desc: Rule 6.2.2 (Required) All declarations of a variable or function shall have the same type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_2_2

Category.desc: Rule 21.6.1 (Advisory) Dynamic memory should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_6_1

Category.desc: Rule 6.2.1 (Required) The one-definition rule shall not be violated
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_2_1

Category.desc: Rule 21.2.4 (Required) The macro offsetof shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_2_4

Category.desc: Rule 21.2.3 (Required) The library function system from <cstdlib> shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_2_3

Category.desc: Rule 21.2.2 (Required) The string handling functions from <cstring>, <cstdlib>, <cwchar> and <cinttypes> shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-21_2_2

Category.desc: Rule 9.4.1 (Required) All if ... else if constructs shall be terminated with an else statement
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_4_1

Category.desc: Dir 15.8.1 (Required) User-provided copy assignment operators and move assignment operators shall handle self-assignment
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-15_8_1

Category.desc: Rule 9.4.2 (Required) The structure of a switch statement shall be appropriate
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_4_2

Category.desc: Rule 8.19.1 (Advisory) The comma operator should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_19_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.6 (Required) An object with integral, enumerated, or pointer to void type shall not be cast to a pointer type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_6

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.5 (Required) reinterpret_cast shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_5

Category.desc: Rule 18.1.2 (Required) An empty throw shall only occur within the compound-statement of a catch handler
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-18_1_2

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.4 (Required) Casts shall not be performed between a pointer to function and any other type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_4

Category.desc: Rule 18.1.1 (Required) An exception object shall not have pointer type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-18_1_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.3 (Required) A cast shall not remove any const or volatile qualification from the type accessed via a pointer or by reference
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_3

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.9 (Required) The operand to typeid shall not be an expression of polymorphic class type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_9

Category.desc: Rule 0.0.1 (Required) A function shall not contain unreachable statements
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 18.5.2 (Advisory) Program-terminating functions should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-18_5_2

Category.desc: Rule 19.3.5 (Required) Tokens that look like a preprocessing directive shall not occur within a macro argument
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_3_5

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.8 (Required) An object pointer type shall not be cast to an integral type other than std::uintptr_t or std::intptr_t
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_8

Category.desc: Rule 0.0.2 (Advisory) Controlling expressions should not be invariant
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_0_2

Category.desc: Rule 18.5.1 (Advisory) A noexcept function should not attempt to propagate an exception to the calling function
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-18_5_1

Category.desc: Rule 19.3.4 (Required) Parentheses shall be used to ensure macro arguments are expanded appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_3_4

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.7 (Advisory) A cast should not convert a pointer type to an integral type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_7

Category.desc: Rule 15.0.2 (Advisory) User-provided copy and move member functions of a class should have appropriate signatures
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-15_0_2

Category.desc: Rule 19.3.3 (Required) The argument to a mixed-use macro parameter shall not be subject to further expansion
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_3_3

Category.desc: Rule 15.0.1 (Required) Special member functions shall be provided appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-15_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 19.3.2 (Required) A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not be immediately followed by a ## operator
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_3_2

Category.desc: Rule 19.3.1 (Advisory) The # and ## preprocessor operators should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.2 (Required) C-style casts and functional notation casts shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_2

Category.desc: Rule 10.3.1 (Advisory) There should be no unnamed namespaces in header files
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-10_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.2.1 (Required) A virtual base class shall only be cast to a derived class by means of dynamic_cast
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_2_1

Category.desc: Rule 12.2.1 (Advisory) Bit-fields should not be declared
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-12_2_1

Category.desc: Rule 12.2.3 (Required) A named bit-field with signed integer type shall not have a length of one bit
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-12_2_3

Category.desc: Rule 12.2.2 (Required) A bit-field shall have an appropriate type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-12_2_2

Category.desc: Rule 16.5.2 (Required) The address-of operator shall not be overloaded
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-16_5_2

Category.desc: Rule 16.5.1 (Required) The logical AND and logical OR operators shall not be overloaded
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-16_5_1

Category.desc: Rule 6.7.2 (Required) Global variables shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_7_2

Category.desc: Rule 6.7.1 (Required) Local variables shall not have static storage duration
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_7_1

Category.desc: Rule 23.11.1 (Advisory) The raw pointer constructors of std::shared_ptr and std::unique_ptr should not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-23_11_1

Category.desc: Rule 5.13.1 (Required) Within character literals and non raw-string literals, \ shall only be used to form a defined escape sequence or universal character name
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_13_1

Category.desc: Rule 9.3.1 (Required) The body of an iteration-statement or a selection-statement shall be a compound-statement
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-9_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 5.13.3 (Required) Octal constants shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_13_3

Category.desc: Rule 5.13.2 (Required) Octal escape sequences, hexadecimal escape sequences and universal character names shall be terminated
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_13_2

Category.desc: Rule 14.1.1 (Advisory) Non-static data members should be either all private or all public
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-14_1_1

Category.desc: Dir 0.3.2 (Required) A function call shall not violate the function's preconditions
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_3_2

Category.desc: Rule 5.13.5 (Required) The lowercase form of "L" shall not be used as the first character in a literal suffix
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_13_5

Category.desc: Rule 11.6.3 (Required) Within an enumerator list, the value of an implicitly-specified enumeration constant shall be unique
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-11_6_3

Category.desc: Rule 5.13.4 (Required) Unsigned integer literals shall be appropriately suffixed
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_13_4

Category.desc: Rule 11.6.2 (Mandatory) The value of an object must not be read before it has been set
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-11_6_2

Category.desc: Rule 5.13.7 (Required) String literals with different encoding prefixes shall not be concatenated
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_13_7

Category.desc: Rule 11.6.1 (Advisory) All variables should be initialized
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-11_6_1

Category.desc: Rule 22.3.1 (Required) The assert macro shall not be used with a constant-expression
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-22_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 5.13.6 (Required) An integer-literal of type long long shall not use a single L or l in any suffix
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-5_13_6

Category.desc: Dir 0.3.1 (Advisory) Floating-point arithmetic should be used appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-0_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.9.1 (Required) The built-in relational operators >, >=, < and <= shall not be applied to objects of pointer type, except where they point to elements of the same array
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_9_1

Category.desc: Rule 10.0.1 (Advisory) A declaration should not declare more than one variable or member variable
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-10_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 19.0.4 (Advisory) #undef should only be used for macros defined previously in the same file
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_0_4

Category.desc: Rule 19.0.3 (Advisory) #include directives should only be preceded by preprocessor directives or comments
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_0_3

Category.desc: Rule 10.4.1 (Required) The asm declaration shall not be used
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-10_4_1

Category.desc: Rule 19.0.2 (Required) Function-like macros shall not be defined
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_0_2

Category.desc: Rule 19.0.1 (Required) A line whose first token is # shall be a valid preprocessing directive
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-19_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 8.1.2 (Advisory) Variables should be captured explicitly in a non-transient lambda
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_1_2

Category.desc: Rule 8.1.1 (Required) A non-transient lambda shall not implicitly capture this
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-8_1_1

Category.desc: Rule 13.3.4 (Required) A comparison of a potentially virtual pointer to member function shall only be with nullptr
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-13_3_4

Category.desc: Rule 13.3.3 (Required) The parameters in all declarations or overrides of a function shall either be unnamed or have identical names
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-13_3_3

Category.desc: Rule 13.3.2 (Required) Parameters in an overriding virtual function shall not specify different default arguments
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-13_3_2

Category.desc: Rule 17.8.1 (Required) Function templates shall not be explicitly specialized
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-17_8_1

Category.desc: Rule 26.3.1 (Advisory) std::vector should not be specialized with bool
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-26_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 7.11.3 (Required) A conversion from function type to pointer-to-function type shall only occur in appropriate contexts
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_11_3

Category.desc: Rule 7.11.2 (Required) An array passed as a function argument shall not decay to a pointer
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_11_2

Category.desc: Rule 7.11.1 (Required) nullptr shall be the only form of the null-pointer-constant
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-7_11_1

Category.desc: Rule 16.6.1 (Advisory) Symmetrical operators should only be implemented as non-member functions
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-16_6_1

Category.desc: Rule 6.8.4 (Advisory) Member functions returning references to their object should be ref-qualified appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_8_4

Category.desc: Rule 6.8.3 (Required) An assignment operator shall not assign the address of an object with automatic storage duration to an object with a greater lifetime
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_8_3

Category.desc: Rule 13.3.1 (Required) User-declared member functions shall use the virtual, override and final specifiers appropriately
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-13_3_1

Category.desc: Rule 6.8.2 (Mandatory) A function must not return a reference or a pointer to a local variable with automatic storage duration
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_8_2

Category.desc: Rule 6.8.1 (Required) An object shall not be accessed outside of its lifetime
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_8_1

Category.desc: Rule 6.4.3 (Required) A name that is present in a dependent base shall not be resolved by unqualified lookup
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_4_3

Category.desc: Rule 25.5.3 (Mandatory) The pointer returned by the C++ Standard Library functions asctime, ctime, gmtime, localtime, localeconv, getenv, setlocale or strerror must not be used following a subsequent call to the same function
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-25_5_3

Category.desc: Rule 6.4.2 (Required) Derived classes shall not conceal functions that are inherited from their bases
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_4_2

Category.desc: Rule 6.4.1 (Required) A variable declared in an inner scope shall not hide a variable declared in an outer scope
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_4_1

Category.desc: Rule 6.0.4 (Required) The identifier main shall not be used for a function other than the global function main
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_0_4

Category.desc: Rule 6.0.3 (Advisory) The only declarations in the global namespace should be main, namespace declarations and extern "C" declarations
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_0_3

Category.desc: Rule 6.0.2 (Advisory) When an array with external linkage is declared, its size should be explicitly specified
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_0_2

Category.desc: Rule 6.0.1 (Required) Block scope declarations shall not be visually ambiguous
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-6_0_1

Category.desc: Rule 25.5.1 (Required) The setlocale and std::locale::global functions shall not be called
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-25_5_1

Category.desc: Rule 25.5.2 (Mandatory) The pointers returned by the C++ Standard Library functions localeconv, getenv, setlocale or strerror must only be used as if they have pointer to const-qualified type
Category.name: MISRACPP2023-25_5_2

Rule.desc: There shall be no unreachable code in "else" block
There shall be no unreachable code after 'return', 'break', 'continue', 'goto', 'throw' statements, and after calls to functions with the 'noreturn' attribute
There shall be no unreachable code in "if/else/while/for" block
There shall be no unreachable code in switch statement
There shall be no unreachable code in 'for' loop
There shall be no unreachable code after 'if' or 'switch' statement
There shall be no unreachable code after "if" or "switch" statement inside while/for/do...while loop
Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block for a derived class and some or all of its bases, the handlers shall be ordered most-derived to base class
Where multiple handlers are provided in a single 'try-catch' statement or 'function-try-block', any ellipsis (catch-all) handler shall occur last
A 'try' statement of a 'try-block' should contain a potentially-throwing statement
Avoid conditions that always evaluate to the same value
Avoid unused values
The value returned by a function having a non-void return type that is not an overloaded operator shall always be used
A project should not contain unused local variables
A project should not contain unused variables with internal linkage
Eliminate unused parameters
There shall be no unused named parameters in virtual functions
Types declared in an unnamed namespace scope should be used at least once
Types declared in a block scope should be used at least once
Avoid unreachable methods
Do not use object representations to compare floating-point values
Floating-point expressions shall not be explicitly (syntactically) tested for equality (==) or inequality (!=)
Do not use floating point variables as loop counters
Do not use floating-point expressions which may result in NaN and infinity values
Do not pass incorrect values to library functions
Each variable should be declared in a separate declaration statement
A pointer parameter in a function prototype should be declared as pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object
Declare a type of parameter as typedef to pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object
Declare reference parameters as const references whenever possible
The volatile qualifier shall be used appropriately
An enumeration shall be defined with an explicit underlying type
An explicit or implicit enumerator value shall not be the result of a narrowing conversion
Unscoped enumerations should not be declared
The numeric value of an unscoped enumeration with no fixed underlying type shall not be used
There shall be no unnamed namespaces in header files
The 'asm' declaration should not be used
C-style arrays shall not be used
The declaration of objects should contain no more than 2 levels of pointer indirection
All non-class variables with automatic storage duration should be explicitly initialized
Avoid use before initialization
Within an enumerator list, the value of an implicitly-specified enumeration constant shall be unique
Do not declare member variables as bit-fields
A bit-field shall have an appropriate type
All enumeration values should be representable within the width of the bit-field
Named bit-fields with signed integer type shall have a length of more than one bit
The union keyword should not be used
Classes should not be derived from virtual bases
A base class shall not be both virtual and non-virtual in the same hierarchy
Each overriding virtual function shall be declared with the override or final specifier
Only one of virtual, override or final should be specified in a member function declaration
Parameters in an overriding virtual function shall not specify different default arguments
The identifiers used in the declaration and definition of a function shall be identical
The parameters in all overrides of a function should either be unnamed or have identical names
A potentially virtual pointer to member function shall only be compared with nullptr
Non-static data members should be either all private or all public
Special member functions shall be provided appropriately
Destructor shall have a non-empty body
User-provided copy and move member functions of a class should have appropriate signatures
Do not use dynamic type of an object under construction
Do not use dynamic type of an object under destruction
All constructors of a class should explicitly call a constructor for all of its immediate base classes and all virtual base classes
Constructors allowing for conversion should be made explicit
User-conversion cast operators should be made explicit
All direct, non-static data members of a non-aggregate class should be initialized at the top of a constructor body
All direct, non-static data members of an aggregate class should be initialized as soon as the object is created
A class shall only define an initializer-list constructor when it is the only constructor
User-provided copy assignment operators shall handle self-assignment
User-provided move assignment operators shall handle self-assignment
Avoid overloading logical operators AND, OR (&&, ||)
The unary & operator shall not be overloaded
Symmetrical operators should only be implemented as non-member functions
Function templates shall not be explicitly specialized
An exception object should not have pointer type
An empty throw shall only be used in the compound-statement of a catch handler
There should be at least one exception handler to catch all otherwise unhandled exceptions
A class type exception shall always be caught by reference
Handlers of a function-try-block implementation of a class constructor or destructor shall not reference nonstatic members from this class or its bases
Exception-unfriendly functions shall be noexcept
Functions used as initializers of non-constexpr, non-local variables shall be noexcept
Pass only 'noexcept' functions to exception-unfriendly functions
Avoid throwing exceptions from functions that are declared not to throw
The 'abort()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'exit()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'quick_exit()' and '_Exit()' functions from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'terminate' function should not be used
Preprocessing directives shall be syntactically meaningful even when excluded by the preprocessor
Function-like macros shall not be defined
#include statements in a file should only be preceded by other preprocessor directives or comments
#undef should only be used for macros defined previously in the same file
The defined preprocessor operator shall only be used in one of the two standard forms
All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if or #ifdef directive to which they are related
Do not use in preprocessor directives #if and #elif macros not defined in translation unit
Use unique multiple include guards
The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence
Non-standard characters should not occur in header file names in #include directives
The # and ## preprocessor operators should not be used
A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not immediately be followed by a ## operator
A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators
In the definition of a function-like macro each instance of a parameter shall be enclosed in parentheses unless it is used as the operand of # or ##
Arguments to a function-like macro shall not contain tokens that look like preprocessing directives
The #pragma directive shall not be used
The '_Pragma' operator should not be used
The identifiers va_list, va_arg, va_start, va_end, va_copy should not be used
The facilities provided by <setjmp.h> should not be used
The standard header files <setjmp.h> or <csetjmp> shall not be used
The signal handling facilities of <signal.h>, except for a call to the 'signal()' function with a value of SIG_IGN, shall not be used
The 'atof', 'atoi', 'atol' and 'atoll' functions from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library should not be used
The string handling functions from <cstring>, <cstdlib>, <cwchar> and <cinttypes> shall not be used
The 'system()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library should not be used
The macro offsetof, in library stddef.h, shall not be used
Dynamic heap memory allocation shall not be used
Dynamic heap memory allocation shall not be used
Any member function named 'allocate' or 'deallocate' enclosed by namespace 'std' should not be used
The 'std::unique_ptr::release' function should not be used
Destructor should not be called manually
Do not declare the 'new' and 'delete' operators
The memory management functions from the <new> and <memory> headers should not be used
Advanced memory management operators 'new' and 'delete' should not be used
Define both sized and unsized versions of operator delete
Do not delete objects with incomplete class at the point of deletion
The 'assert' macro shall not be used with a constant expression
The literal value zero shall be the only value assigned to errno
The raw pointer constructors of 'std::shared_ptr' and 'std::unique_ptr' should not be used
The character handling functions from <cctype> and <cwctype> shall not be used
The C++ Standard Library functions 'memcpy', 'memmove' and 'memcmp' from <cstring> should not be used
The 'setlocale' function should not be used
The 'std::locale::global' function should not be used
The pointers returned by the Standard Library functions 'localeconv', 'getenv', 'setlocale' or, 'strerror' shall only be used as if they have pointer to const-qualified type
Strings pointed by members of the structure 'lconv' should not be modified
The address of the 'localeconv', 'getenv', 'setlocale' or, 'strerror' function should not be taken
Pointers returned by certain Standard Library functions should not be used following a subsequent call to the same or related function
Avoid using vector<bool>
Predicates shall not have persistent side effects
Do not use std::move on objects declared with the const or const & type
The 'std::forward' function should be used to forward forwarding references
The 'std::forward' function should only be used to forward forwarding references
Do not subsequently use the argument to std::forward
Do not rely on the value of a moved-from object
The result of std::remove, std::remove_if, std::unique and empty shall be used
The input/output library stdio.h shall not be used
The input/output functions from the 'cstdio' and 'cwchar' libraries should not be used
Do not alternately input and output from a stream without an intervening flush or positioning call
Do not include headers deprecated in the C++17 standard
The 'uncaught_exception' function deprecated in the C++17 standard should not be used
Do not use throw exception specifications
A constexpr static data member should not be declared outside the class definition
Avoid incorrect shift operations
Avoid signed integer overflows
Avoid null pointer dereferencing
Avoid division by zero
The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call
Between sequence points an object shall have its stored value modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression
Do not use more than one volatile between two adjacent sequence points
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function calls
Trigraphs shall not be used
Do not declare entities in the standard library namespaces: posix, std and stdN
Do not use identifiers which begin with one or two underscores (`_' or `__')
An identifier shall not contain a double underscore '__'
User defined suffixes of the user defined literal operators shall start with underscore followed by one or more letters
A user-defined literal suffix should be directly preceded by a literal operator
A macro identifier should have an appropriate form
Do not declare identifiers with names reserved in the standard library
Only those escape sequences that are defined in ISO/IEC 14882:2014 shall be used
Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated
Octal constants (other than zero) shall not be used
A 'U' suffix shall be applied to all constants of unsigned type
The lowercase form of 'L' shall not be used as the first character in a literal suffix
An integer-literal of type long long shall not use a single 'L' or 'l' in any suffix
String literals with different encoding prefixes shall not be concatenated
String literals with and without encoding prefixes should not be concatenated
The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C-style comment
Sections of code should not be "commented out"
Line-splicing shall not be used in // comments
Always declare functions at file scope
Parameter names in function declarations should not be enclosed in parentheses
Local variable names in variable declarations should not be enclosed in parentheses
When an array with external linkage is declared, its size should be explicitly specified
The global namespace shall only contain main() and namespace declarations
The identifier main shall not be used for a function other than the global function main
The One Definition Rule shall not be violated
All declarations of an object or function shall have compatible types
If a function is declared with an exception-specification, then all declarations of the same function (in other translation units) shall be declared with the same set of type-ids
An identifier with external linkage shall have no more then one external definition
A type that is used in multiple translation units shall be defined in one and only one file
An inline function that is used in multiple translation units shall be defined in one and only one file
Template specialization shall be declared in the same file as the primary template or a user-defined type, for which the specialization is declared
A header file shall not contain definitions of functions or objects that are non-inline and have external linkage
Member variable names in derived classes should not be the same as member variable names in base classes
A variable declared in an inner scope shall not hide a variable declared in an outer scope
Member functions declared in derived classes should not hide equivalent functions declared in base classes
Member functions declared in derived classes should not hide non-equivalent functions declared in base classes
In a class template with a dependent base, any name that may be found in that dependent base shall be referred to using a qualified-id or this->
Objects or functions with external linkage shall be declared in a header file
Do not use static keyword except inside functions and classes
Identifiers shall not simultaneously have both internal and external linkage in the same translation unit
Local variables shall not have static storage duration
Global variables and static data members should not be used
Do not point to a wrapped object that has been freed
Do not read the value of a non-active union field
Do not use an object after its lifetime has ended
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
Never return lambdas that capture local objects by reference
The address of an object with automatic storage duration shall not be assigned to an object with a greater lifetime
Member functions returning references to their object should be ref-qualified appropriately
The same type aliases shall be used in all declarations of the same entity
The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used
There shall be no conversion from type bool
There shall be no conversion to type bool
The numerical value of a character shall not be used
Operands of bitwise and complement operators shall have an unsigned type
Operands of shift operators shall have an unsigned type
Integral promotion and the usual arithmetic conversions shall not change the signedness or the type category of an operand
Assignment between numeric types shall be appropriate
Prefer 'nullptr' over 'NULL' or '0'(zero)
The 'NULL' identifier should not be used
An object of array type should not decay to a pointer when it is passed as a function argument
An object of array type should not be passed as a variadic argument to a function
A conversion from function type to pointer-to-function type shall only occur in appropriate contexts
The operand of the 'sizeof' operator should be enclosed in parentheses
Use parentheses to indicate the precedence of operators in expressions
The right-hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain side effects
An object shall not be assigned or copied to an overlapping object
An object shall not be assigned to an overlapping object
An object shall not be assigned to an overlapping object
The result of an assignment operator should not be used
The comma operator shall not be used
A non-transient lambda shall not implicitly capture this
Variables should be captured explicitly in a non-transient lambda
Evaluation of constant unsigned integer expressions should not lead to wrap-around
Evaluation of constant unsigned integer expressions in preprocessor directives should not lead to wraparound
A pointer to a virtual base class shall only be cast to a pointer to a derived class by means of dynamic_cast
Do not use recursion
An argument passed via ellipsis shall have an appropriate type
C-style casts (other than void casts) and functional notation casts (other than explicit constructor calls) shall not be used
A conversion shall not remove any 'const', 'volatile' or '_Atomic' qualification from the type accessed via a pointer or by reference
Casts shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any other type
Avoid using reinterpret_cast
An object with integer type or pointer to void type shall not be converted to an object with pointer type
An object with enumeration type shall not be converted to an object with pointer type
A cast should not convert a pointer type to an integral type
A cast should not convert a pointer type to 'intptr_t' and 'uintptr_t' types
A cast should not convert a pointer type to an integral type
The operand to typeid shall not be an expression of polymorphic class type
The unary minus operator shall not be applied to an expression whose underlying type is unsigned
The built-in unary + operator should not be used
Avoid accessing arrays out of bounds
A pointer operand and any pointer resulting from pointer arithmetic using that operand shall both address elements of the same array
Avoid overflow when reading from a buffer
Avoid overflow when writing to a buffer
Avoid overflow due to reading a not zero terminated string
Do not subtract two pointers that do not address elements of the same array
Do not compare two unrelated pointers
Expression statements shall not be explicit calls to constructors of temporary objects only
The statement forming the body of a 'switch', 'while', 'do...while' or 'for' statement shall be a compound statement
'if' and 'else' should be followed by a compound statement
All 'if...else-if' constructs shall be terminated with an 'else' clause
The first or the last label of a switch statement should be the 'default' label unless all enumeration values are tested
Every switch branch should be unconditionally terminated
A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement
A switch statement shall only contain switch labels and switch clauses, and no other code
Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses
The 'switch' statement should not contain labels other than 'case' and 'default'
The condition of a 'switch' statement should only be preceded by an optional simple-declaration
Legacy 'for' statements should be simple
A for-range-initializer shall contain at most one function call
The goto statement shall not be used
Any label referenced by a goto statement shall be declared in the same block, or in a block enclosing the goto statement
The goto statement shall jump to a label declared later in the same function body
Never return from functions that should not return
All exit paths from a function, except main(), with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression

StdViol.msg: <stdio.h> library shall not be used
StdViol.rule.header: The input/output library stdio.h shall not be used

StdViol.msg: Variable 'buf' should be explicitly initialized
StdViol.rule.header: All non-class variables with automatic storage duration should be explicitly initialized

StdViol.msg: Do not convert an object with integer type 'int' to an object with pointer type 'void *'
StdViol.rule.header: An object with integer type or pointer to void type shall not be converted to an object with pointer type

StdViol.msg: The 'sprintf' library function should not be used
StdViol.rule.header: The input/output functions from the 'cstdio' and 'cwchar' libraries should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not pass an object of array type as an argument to the 'sprintf' function
StdViol.rule.header: An object of array type should not decay to a pointer when it is passed as a function argument

StdViol.msg: Do not pass an object of array type as an argument to the 'print_string' function
StdViol.rule.header: An object of array type should not decay to a pointer when it is passed as a function argument

StdViol.msg: Parameter 'new_time' is not used
StdViol.rule.header: Eliminate unused parameters

StdViol.msg: <stdio.h> library shall not be used
StdViol.rule.header: The input/output library stdio.h shall not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Function 'print_menu_get_action' has external linkage and is not declared in the header
StdViol.rule.header: Objects or functions with external linkage shall be declared in a header file

StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Variable 'res' should be explicitly initialized
StdViol.rule.header: All non-class variables with automatic storage duration should be explicitly initialized

StdViol.msg: Declare variable 'i' in a separate declaration statement
StdViol.rule.header: Each variable should be declared in a separate declaration statement

StdViol.rule.header: The input/output library stdio.h shall not be used

StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Global variable 'max_records' has external linkage and is not declared in the header
StdViol.rule.header: Objects or functions with external linkage shall be declared in a header file

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not pass an object of array type as an argument to the 'memset' function
StdViol.rule.header: An object of array type should not decay to a pointer when it is passed as a function argument

StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Variable 'i' should be explicitly initialized
StdViol.rule.header: All non-class variables with automatic storage duration should be explicitly initialized

StdViol.msg: The 'for' init-statement should only declare and initialize a loop-counter of integer type
StdViol.rule.header: Legacy 'for' statements should be simple

StdViol.msg: Function 'query_user' has external linkage and is not declared in the header
StdViol.rule.header: Objects or functions with external linkage shall be declared in a header file

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Variable 'start_m' should be explicitly initialized
StdViol.rule.header: All non-class variables with automatic storage duration should be explicitly initialized

StdViol.msg: Local variable 'start_m' declared but not used
StdViol.rule.header: A project should not contain unused local variables

StdViol.rule.header: Dynamic heap memory allocation shall not be used

StdViol.rule.header: Assignment between numeric types shall be appropriate

StdViol.rule.header: All non-class variables with automatic storage duration should be explicitly initialized

StdViol.msg: Local variable 'c' declared but not used
StdViol.rule.header: A project should not contain unused local variables

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Variable 'i' should be explicitly initialized
StdViol.rule.header: All non-class variables with automatic storage duration should be explicitly initialized

StdViol.msg: Variable 'buf' should be explicitly initialized
StdViol.rule.header: All non-class variables with automatic storage duration should be explicitly initialized

StdViol.msg: The 'isdigit' function should not be used
StdViol.rule.header: The character handling functions from <cctype> and <cwctype> shall not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not declare the 'index' local variable with static storage duration
StdViol.rule.header: Local variables shall not have static storage duration

StdViol.msg: There shall be no conversion from type 'int' to type 'char'
StdViol.rule.header: The numerical value of a character shall not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'atoi' function
StdViol.rule.header: The 'atof', 'atoi', 'atol' and 'atoll' functions from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not pass an object of array type as an argument to the 'atoi' function
StdViol.rule.header: An object of array type should not decay to a pointer when it is passed as a function argument

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Pass parameter "str" with const specifier
StdViol.rule.header: A pointer parameter in a function prototype should be declared as pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object

StdViol.msg: The 'printf' library function should not be used
StdViol.rule.header: The input/output functions from the 'cstdio' and 'cwchar' libraries should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use characters other than uppercase letters, numbers, and underscores in a macro name: _consts_h_
StdViol.rule.header: A macro identifier should have an appropriate form

StdViol.msg: Do not use characters other than uppercase letters, numbers, and underscores in a macro name: _clock_h_
StdViol.rule.header: A macro identifier should have an appropriate form

StdViol.msg: Do not use characters other than uppercase letters, numbers, and underscores in a macro name: _input_h_
StdViol.rule.header: A macro identifier should have an appropriate form

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use characters other than uppercase letters, numbers, and underscores in a macro name: _timer_h_
StdViol.rule.header: A macro identifier should have an appropriate form

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'unsigned' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used

StdViol.msg: Do not use the 'int' standard integer type
StdViol.rule.header: The names of the standard signed integer types and standard unsigned integer types should not be used
